title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: invaded England, he reduced Wark and Etal, and then occupied Ford Castle, which he made headquarters.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Etal looks now with its trellised cottages and blooming flower-knots, the very impersonation of quiet and repose; and if the banks of the river are not delighted with the melody of " the shepherd' s reed " — an instrument I never heard, or any body else, I fancy — they certainly are not "startled by the bugle-horn ;" and Scott's line might be equally applied to Till as Teviot —

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: Etal is the Northumbrian Auburn, and no sweeter village was ever resorted to wherein to pass a honeymoon.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:
author: Maxwell, W. H.
snippet: From its position being in advance of the more important castles of Etal and Ford, it might have been designed as well for a look-out tower, as a house of defence, in order to give notice to the garrisons of these places, that the unruly Borderers on the Scottish side were once more in the saddle ; and telegraph by the signal-fires then in use, whether the invasion were but a predatory foray, or, on the more extended scale of operations termed *' a warden raid."

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: A strong garrisonwas maintained in that city, ready at all times forservice; and, to have kept Berwick-upon-Tweed,was of itself a sufficient praise for a military man,and sums up, in a minstrel ballad, the character ofHarry Hotspur himself.6 When garrisons of regular troops were lodged, as was usually the case,in the royal castle of Norham, and Lord Grey'sbaronial castle of Wark, with smaller parties inthose of Etal, Ford, Cornhill, and Twizell, thecourse of the Tweed, where it divides the kingdoms, was well protected from invasion; and thenecessary siege of one or other of this chain of

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: Her husband, Earl John, foundit when storming the Enghsh castle of Etal, and hadgiven it to his confessor, as a book of magic; for to theunlettered warrior of the fifteenth century, its strangeblack characters seemed the very work of beU, and hehad never touched the volume, save with his gauntletson.
